raw_text:
Mogul Wilson backing UK rap band
 
 Tony Wilson, the music mogul who established the influential Factory Records in the 1980s, is to launch a new label - convinced he has discovered his "third major band".
 
 Factory were the label of both Joy Division - who became New Order after singer Ian Curtis committed suicide - and the Happy Mondays. Now Wilson believes rap act Raw T - signed to his F4 label, the fourth incarnation of Factory - will "complete the hat-trick". "Suddenly, when Raw T came into my life, I realised they are my third major band," he told BBC World Service's The Music Biz programme. The group are set to release their first single on 21 February, and follow it up with an album, Realise And Witness, in March.
 
 Wilson has twice tried to resurrect Factory - which lasted for 14 years before folding - but conceded these efforts had been "despondent and dismal experiences". But it has not put him off. "Of all the things I do in my life the most exciting thing I've ever done, and the thing I have most loved, is being part of a record company," he added.
 
 "The idea of working with brilliant young musicians, and being close to the centre of popular culture, is just the biggest thrill in my life." Wilson explained how his son persuaded him to go and see Raw T, but he had initially been reluctant saying he "detested" young British people rapping. "It's always inauthentic, it's always crass, it never really works for me," he said. "I went to see this group, Raw T - which stands for Realise And Witness Talent - and like everyone else in the room that night, we were utterly blown away." Wilson believes Raw T could be "to F4 as Joy Division were to Factory records".
 
 The story of Factory records - which also owned the legendary Hacienda club in Manchester - was told in the Michael Winterbottom film 24 Hour Party People, in which Wilson was played by Steve Coogan.
 
 Wilson stressed that the independent music scene remained "as important" as it had been during the 1980s, when labels such as Factory and Rough Trade proliferated. He pointed out that Franz Ferdinand and The White Stripes - "perhaps the two most important bands since the millennium" - were signed to indies. "I think that is a reflection of how useful and how powerful the indie philosophy is, and how bands prefer it," he added. "They can make more money that way - it's a more generous relationship, and also it's a more understanding relationship. "I think independents are in a wonderful position at this moment in time."
llama3.2:1b: Tony Wilson to launch new label Factory Records, backed by Mogul Wilson, with rapper Raw T. The group is set to release their first single and album Realise And Witness on February 21, March 1.
Wilson had previously tried to revive the Factory label, which folded in 1987.
llama3.2:3b: Tony Wilson to launch new label F4 with UK rap band Raw T, convinced they will complete his "hat-trick" of successful bands after Joy Division and Happy Mondays, following 14-year attempt to revive Factory Records.
gemma2:2b: Tony Wilson, music mogul and founder of Factory Records, is launching a new label called F4 with a focus on rap act Raw T, believing he has discovered his third major band.
Wilson, who previously tried to revive Factory, believes in the power of independent labels like those that flourished during the 1980s.
He cites Franz Ferdinand and The White Stripes' success as examples.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tony Wilson, founder of Factory Records (1980s), backed UK rap band Raw T, signing him to his F4 label, Fourth Incarnation.
Wilson sees Raw T as his third major band and hopes the group will complete the "hat-trick" of Factory records.
He worked on Factory with former Joy Division singer Ian Curtis but later abandoned Factory Records after the group was folded.
Wilson is a music mogul who supports independent labels like F4.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Music mogul Tony Wilson will launch a new record label featuring rap group Raw T, based on his discovery of the band as his third major musical project following Joy Division and Happy Mondays.
Wilson had previously tried to revive Factory Records but failed twice.
He believes Raw T could be as successful as Joy Division was for Factory Records.
qwen2.5:3b: Tony Wilson, founder of Factory Records, backs UK rap band Raw T on his new label F4.
Believing Raw T will complete his "hat-trick" of successful bands, Wilson launched the label after unsuccessful attempts to revive Factory.
He initially disliked rap but changed his mind after seeing Raw T perform live.
Wilson considers Raw T as important for F4 as Joy Division were for Factory Records.
He emphasizes that the independent music scene remains crucial and influential in today's music industry, with bands like Franz Ferdinand and The White Stripes signed by indie labels.
opencoder:1.5b: The story of Mogul Wilson, who launched the UK rap band Factory Records, was told in The Music Biz programme by Tony Wilson, the man behind Factory Records.
The group were set to release their first single on 21 February, and followed up with an album, Realise And Witness, in March.
Wilson has tried to resurrect the band but conceded these efforts had been disappointing.
He believes that Raw T - signed to his F4 label - could be "to Factory as Joy Division were to Factory records".
The independent music scene remained "as important" as it had been during the 1980s, when labels such as Factory and Rough Trade proliferated.
He stressed that the independent philosophy was more effective than any band could possibly hope for.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should preserve the key ideas and details of the original text:

1.

The main idea is that Tony Wilson, the music mogul who established Factory Records in the 1980s, has discovered his "third major band" - Raw T - and believes he has discovered his "complete hat-trick".

The summary should preserve the key details of the original text:
	* The name of the label - Factory Records - is mentioned.
* The name of the artist who founded the label - Tony Wilson - is mentioned.
* The name of the artist who signed Raw T to his F4 label - Raw T - is mentioned.
The summary should not explain or interpret the text, but rather present it in a concise and clear manner.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Tony Wilson is backing Raw T, a rap band.
He has launched a new label for a third major record, having previously folded Factory Records, which was owned by Factory and Hacienda.
Wilson believes he worked with three major bands since Factory folded, including Joy Division and New Order.
His group will release a single on February 21 and an album in March.
Wilson tried to revive the music scene but faced failures, yet didn't give up.
He sees working with young artists as thrilling.
Factory Records also had Hacienda, played by Wilson in a film where he was Steve Coogan.
The independent scene remains important now, despite previous big labels.
tinyllama:1.1b: The music mogul Tony Wilson believes that Raw T is his "third major band," following the success of Joy Division (who became New Order after Ian Curtis committed suicide), and Happy Monday (another Factory Records act).
He sees the UK rap group as his "third major band" due to their "genuine talent" and "crazy potential."
Wilson believes Raw T could complete the "hat-trick" of Factory's previous labels, adding that the independent music scene remains "as important" as it was during the 1980s.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Mogul Wilson has just launched a new major label called F4, marking his return to the music industry after an absence of four decades.
In addition to launching a hip-hop group named Raw T, he is also thrilled by the prospect of rekindling another part of Factory Records' legacy.
The Happy Mondays, a legendary British rock band signed to Factory in the 1980s, are set to release their first single, titled "Suddenly," on February 21st.
Following this, they will release an album called Realize and Witness on March 15th.
phi:2.7b: Tony Wilson, the founder of Factory Records who established influential bands like Joy Division and Happy Mondays, is launching a new label called F4 with rapper Raw T, his "third major band".
The group will release their first single on 21 February and an album in March.

Despite previously trying to resurrect Factory twice and feeling despondent about it, Wilson's love for being part of a record company has not waned, and he believes that the indie music scene remains just as important today as it was during the 90s.
He points out that bands like Franz Ferdinand and The White Stripes, who have achieved great success in recent years, were signed to independent labels.
Wilson is excited about Raw T's potential and sees them as "to F4 as Joy Division was to Factory records".

The group's single and album are set to be released in 2021.
Wilson has been involved in the music industry for several decades and was a key figure in the independent music scene during the 1980s, founding Factory Records and owning the Hacienda nightclub.
He believes Raw T shares the same philosophy as the bands he backed in the past and is excited about the prospect of a third major band under his label.
The story of Factory records has been told in the Michael Winterbottom film 24 Hour Party People, with Wilson played by Steve Coogan.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Tony Wilson, the creator of Factory Records, now plans to launch F4, his fourth label, focusing on UK rap band Raw T, which he sees as his "third major band" after Joy Division (now New Order) and Happy Mondays.

Despite previous failed attempts to revive Factory, Wilson remains passionate about the music industry, emphasizing its significance in popular culture and contemporary importance for bands like Franz Ferdinand and The White Stripes.
He was initially skeptical of rap but was impressed by Raw T after his son introduced him.
Wilson believes Raw T could emulate Joy Division's influence on Factory Records, reflecting the enduring appeal of independent music scenes.
